Wrong Answer Text: ![A graph showing a straight line from top left to bottom right.]()

MisconceptionName: Confuses cubic and quadratic graphs
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph? 
Correct Answer Text: ![A graph that starts in the top left, drops steeply down as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply up back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical U shape.]() 
Wrong Answer Text: ![A graph showing a curve that starts in the bottom left, moves steeply up and right, levels off briefly, then continues steeply up and right.]()

MisconceptionName: Confuses reciprocal and quadratic graphs
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph? 
Correct Answer Text: ![A graph that starts in the top left, drops steeply down as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply up back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical U shape.]() 
Wrong Answer Text: ![A graph with two curves. One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the y axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x axis.
The other curve is in the negative x, negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left close to the x axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the y axis then becomes almost vertical to travel almost parallel to the y axis. ]()

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct? 
Correct Answer Text: Only
Katie 
Wrong Answer Text: Only
Tom

MisconceptionName: When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct? 
Correct Answer Text: Only
Katie 
Wrong Answer Text: Both Tom and Katie

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.
LLM_Response:
Question Text: What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q \)s in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
\begin{array}{cc}
  Pair 1 & Pair 2 \\
\( 2p-4q=6 \) & \( 2p-4q=6 \)\\
\( 7p+4q=9 \) & \( 7p-4q=9 \)
\end{array}
 
Correct Answer Text: Add Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Add Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, regardless of the signs of the terms with matching coefficients, we subtract the equations
LLM_Response:
Question Text: What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q \)s in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
\begin{array}{cc}
  Pair 1 & Pair 2 \\
\( 2p-4q=6 \) & \( 2p-4q=6 \)\\
\( 7p+4q=9 \) & \( 7p-4q=9 \)
\end{array}
 
Correct Answer Text: Add Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)

Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}(-3,0) \\ \text { and } \\ (-5,0)\end{array} \)

MisconceptionName: Believes both the x and y co-ordinates of the x-intercept of a quadratic are derived from the constants in the factorised form.

MisconceptionName: Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine

MisconceptionName: When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation

Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{l}x=3 \\ y=-5\end{array} \)

MisconceptionName: Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order

Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \)

Problem Q: \( 3 \times 5 \)

Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \times 5= \)

Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Problem P: \( 3+5 \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \)

MisconceptionName: Believes constructing a perpendicular gives an angle of 60 degrees

Correct Answer Text: - Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width equal to the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Draw a straight line from the ends of each line to where the arcs intersect 
Wrong Answer Text: - Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Join up where the lines intersect

Who is correct? 
Correct Answer Text: Neither is correct 
Wrong Answer Text: Only
Tom

Correct Answer Text: Neither is correct

MisconceptionName: Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction
LLM_Response:
Question Text: STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: \( \frac{4}{3 x-1} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \frac{12}{9 x-1} \)

MisconceptionName: When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors
LLM_Response:
Question Text: STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: \( \frac{4}{3 x-1} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \frac{4(3 x+1)}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)} \)

MisconceptionName: Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator
LLM_Response:
Question Text: STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: \( \frac{4}{3 x-1} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \frac{5}{3 x} \)

Question Text: ![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \). 
Correct Answer Text: Left \( 5 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares 
Wrong Answer Text: Left \( 4 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares

MisconceptionName: When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original
LLM_Response:
Question Text: ![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \). 
Correct Answer Text: Left \( 5 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares 
Wrong Answer Text: Right \( 5 \) squares, up \( 3 \) squares

MisconceptionName: When describing a translation, identifies the correct number of jumps but mixes up the directions .
LLM_Response:
Question Text: ![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \). 
Correct Answer Text: Left \( 5 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares 
Wrong Answer Text: Left \( 5 \) squares, up \( 3 \) squares

A letter "A" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 3 squares above the red line. A letter "B" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 2 squares above the red line. A letter "C" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 1 square above the red line. A letter "D" is marking a point 6 squares along from the tiny blue circle and 3 squares above the red line. ]() 
Correct Answer Text: A 
Wrong Answer Text: C

MisconceptionName: Rotates instead of reflects

Horizontally, the rectangle is exactly in the middle of the grid. Vertically, the rectangle is 1 square down from the red line. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with a tiny blue circle.
A letter "A" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 3 squares above the red line. A letter "B" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 2 squares above the red line. A letter "C" is marking a point directly above the tiny blue circle, 1 square above the red line. A letter "D" is marking a point 6 squares along from the tiny blue circle and 3 squares above the red line. ]() 
Correct Answer Text: A

Question Text: ![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?

Wrong Answer Text: B

MisconceptionName: Reflects instead of rotates

Question Text: ![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?

Wrong Answer Text: C

\hline Hammerhead & \( 4 \) & \( 45 \) \\

MisconceptionName: Believes linear graphs can be curved

Correct Answer Text: ![A graph showing a straight line from bottom left to top right.]() 
Wrong Answer Text: ![A graph that starts in the top left, drops steeply down as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply up back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical U shape.]()

MisconceptionName: Confuses linear and reciprocal graphs
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function? 
Correct Answer Text: ![A graph showing a straight line from bottom left to top right.]() 
Wrong Answer Text: ![A graph with two curves. One curve is in the negative x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the bottom left close to the x axis, as we move right it rises very quickly towards the y axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the y axis.
The other curve is in the negative y, positive x quadrant. It starts at the bottom left close to the y axis, as we move right it rises very quickly towards the x axis then becomes almost horizontal to travel almost parallel to the x axis. ]()

MisconceptionName: Thinks a variable next to a number means addition rather than multiplication
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Calculate the time taken \( (t) \) for a a particle to travel with acceleration \( (a)=4.1 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=2.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) and final velocity \( (v)=8.7 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) \( t=\frac{1}{a}(v-u) \) 
Correct Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}t=(8.7-2.8) \div 4.1 \\ t=1.44\end{array} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}t=\frac{1}{4.1}+(8.7-2.8) \\ t=6.14\end{array} \)

MisconceptionName: When multiplying fractions, multiplies the denominator
LLM_Response:
Question Text: Calculate the time taken \( (t) \) for a a particle to travel with acceleration \( (a)=4.1 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=2.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) and final velocity \( (v)=8.7 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) \( t=\frac{1}{a}(v-u) \) 
Correct Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}t=(8.7-2.8) \div 4.1 \\ t=1.44\end{array} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}t=4.1 \times(8.7-2.8) \\ t=24.19\end{array} \)

- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot

- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

- Where these lines cross completes the triangle

Correct Answer Text: \( 3 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( 6 \)

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation matching the sign (+ if positive, - if negative)
LLM_Response:
Question Text: What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Add Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.
LLM_Response:
Question Text: What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Add Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)

MisconceptionName: Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation inverse to the sign (- if positive, + if negative)
LLM_Response:
Question Text: What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\) 
Correct Answer Text: Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \) 
Wrong Answer Text: Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)

MisconceptionName: Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem
LLM_Response:
Question Text: This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Dora's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 12 + 4 = 16". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]() 
Correct Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}2+35=37 \\ 0.7+0.9=1.6 \\ 37+1.6=38.6\end{array} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}2.7+35=37.7 \\ 37.7+0.9=38.6\end{array} \)

MisconceptionName: Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal
LLM_Response:
Question Text: This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Dora's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 12 + 4 = 16". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]() 
Correct Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}2+35=37 \\ 0.7+0.9=1.6 \\ 37+1.6=38.6\end{array} \) 
Wrong Answer Text: \( \begin{array}{c}2+35=37 \\ 0.7+0.9=1.6 \\ 37+1.6=37.16\end{array} \)
